long_desc.thetext:
During the recent studies for the data binding the selection of list like elements was a topic. During that, i figured out that the selection API differs from the List to the SelectBox.
The List does have two APIs, one for single selection mode and another for multi selection mode. Those methods only work in the corresponding modes. I think this is a redundancy of API and because the multi selection API would be enough and could handle the single selection as well. Therefore I suggest to deprecate the single selection API and remove it later on. The SelectBox does only have some kind of mini selection API with getSelected and an changeSelected event which again differs from the changeSelection event and getSelection (for multi value) or getSelectedItem (for single value). Therefore the SelectBox could also implement the same API as the list.
To get the API consistent is suggest to write an interface which every widget (list and selectbox) have to implement containing the current multi selection API of List.

I would prefer to keep the single/multi selection difference. These are elementary different storage types. To unify them do not make sense for me.
I would like to have an Interface for single and another one for multi selection types. The List widget must implement both of them. The SelectBox implements the single selection interface.
Changed the milestone and the status. Additionally changed the assignee.
Created attachment 428 Added a PDF comparing the current status and the Interface to implement.
Created attachment 429 Changed some details in the Interface description.
Accepted.
- API changes done in trunk (r17278).

Fixed in trunk (r17327).
- Added unit tests for the selection API - Fixed selection manager: It was possible to select an item which wasn't a child from the widget (e.g. List).
Reopnened.
Created attachment 439 The new ideas of the selection API.

I don't like the recent changes. The main purpose of this bug was to unify the interfaces for single and multi selection. This goal has now been reverted. I don't see any benefit in having a "changeSelected" event in single selection mode and a "changeSelection" event in multi selection mode. Further I think the selectAll method should print a warning and not an error in single selection mode. I would suggest leaving the API as in the first draft. The only change I would make is to rename the "resetSelection" method to "clearSelection" as Sebastian has suggested.

I would suggest the following:
ISingleSelection: - setSelected - getSelected
IMultiSelection: - setSelection - getSelection - selectAll - addSelected (instead of addToSelection) - removeSelected (instead of removeFromSelection)
Common API: - isSelected(item) - clearSelection - changeSelection (event) - hasSelection (instead of isSelectionEmpty)
This is basically my old suggestion but with a few method name improvements to make them handier. Through the case that even in single selection some methods and events are named "selection" it might be a good compromise.
to me. This is still generating a lot of trailing comments, so lets nail this one down.
To me.

Reverted the new Selection API in trunk r18273, that the old API (from 0.8.1) is furthermore valid, also set the new Selection API to experimental.
The new Selection API has to improved for the new 0.8.3 release.

For the 0.8.2 release it was best to go with the 0.8.1 API, instead of a half-baked selection change, that would require yet another migration step for users afterwards. There has finally been a good agreement on how to straighten out this fiddly issue in a future major release: using two distinct and self-consistent interfaces for single selection ("selected") and multi selection ("selection").

We made a list for all the widgets in the framework we thing have some kind of selection handled with widgets as selected items:
Single Selection: - RadioGroup - SelectBox - TabView - Stack Single and Multi Selection: - List - Tree

Following the blog post from 08-04-2009:
Arrays for Single Selection is a killer in suggestions #5. This do not follow the paradigm where simple things should be simple and complex things should be possible. Not to say that a multi selection is complex. But to use SelectBox.setSelection([item]); is completely non-sense. Especially as only and exactly one item is allowed in the list.
I would highly prefer suggestion number 3, but I have a few comments. Especially in regard of my previous comment 11 (#11). In this case the only overlapping methods when using both interfaces are the setter and getters. And even here I don't see such a huge negative impact. For most trees and lists it might be perfectly valid to call setSelected(item) - even in multi-selection lists. How often one really do a multi selection programmatically?
In this suggestion there is only one event defined. One negative point less. I also think that both setters could work in both modes. What should be the problem here? setSelected() would replace the whole selection in multi selection mode. The only thing to verify is that in single selections the setter is called with an array of exactly a length of "one" (maybe "zero") allowed as well.
Bug#1835 and bug#1378 are also depends on changing Selection API.

After receiving quite some feedback during the several rounds of discussion (thanks to everybody for contributing), we've decided to go for the scenario of providing two interfaces (where the multi-selection one derives from the single-selection one), and consistently using lists for holding selections.
This does indeed require array notation even for the trivial single selection case (for sure this isn't perfect, at least not without taking the entire context into account), but it provides a fully consistent API - and equally as important: a consistent concept. The latter should allow to easily communicate that in qooxdoo a selection is always a list of selectable items. The drawback of requiring array notation in the single selection case doesn't outweigh the overall advantages IMHO. Go for it, Chris.

Mhh, still not happy with this. Just to mention a few really ugly cases:
* tabView.getSelection() => [secondTab] * tabView.setSelection([otherTab]);
Horrible. This also breaks the nice APIs were you trying to work with the result:
* selectBox.getSelection().getValue() do not work anymore... instead we have to do: * selectBox.getSelection()[0].getValue()... how bad is this?
Do all people really prefer this style? Are the benefits of this new API really weight out these negative impacts?
I just want to hightlight that one more often (by large extends) configure single selections programmatically then doing this with multiple selections. (Question: Have you ever build an application before where you have applied multi-selections programmatically?) We a going to massively worsen this API in cases of single selections. Anybody seen such an API in any other toolkit out there before? SWT? Qt? Swing?... no?
So enough regarding my "vetoing" ;) Somehow I still hope that somebody see the same issue here...
We will see how the users will like it when they are forced to use it afterwards.

We have also considered your mentioned "ugly" scenarios. Sure it is not the best solution if you only use the single selection api for example in a select box. But as Andreas said, if you take the whole context into account, it is the best solution. I think that we overestimate its importance anyway. After the data binding is finally introduced in qooxdoo, the proper way to deal with a selection will be with the data binding controllers. And for the data binding itself, its a good solution to go with the mentioned structure.

The question is where is this "context". Nobody never documented the way which led to this conclusion. It would be helpful for any kind of argumentation if the chosen way has documentation which led to this result.
To force users to use data binding to get an acceptable selection API is sure one way one could go - still not a good one though. Especially for widgets which as normally not controlled by data binding like TabViews or Accordions etc this definitely not help a lot.

Accepted.
And removed not applicable dependence.

Update: - implemented changes for List and Tree - reviewed framework for the new methods (used the new one) - updated unit test for single and multi selection (Tree and List)
Done with reversion 18823.

Update: - implemented changes for SelectBox - created a single selection manager for all single selection widgets - reviewed framework for the new methods (used the new one) - updated unit tests for the SelectBox
Done with reversion 18857

Update: - implemented changes for RadioGroup - reviewed framework for the new methods (used the new one) - updated unit tests for the RadioGroup
Done with reversion 18865

Update: - implemented changes for TabView - reviewed framework for the new methods (used the new one) - updated unit tests for the TabView
Done with reversion 18896.

Update: - implemented changes for Stack - reviewed framework for the new methods (used the new one) - updated unit tests for the Stack
Done with reversion 18906

The old selection API is set to deprecated, but also valid. So the users from the old selection API gets a deprecation warning in the source version of the application when he uses the old API. The old selection API has only one new thing, if the selection try to select a element which is not a child element, an exception is thrown.
Implemented all changes for the new selection API with reversion 18934. List of widgets that implements the new selection API: - qx.ui.tree.Tree (IMultiSelection) - qx.ui.form.List (IMultiSelection) - qx.ui.form.SelectBox (ISingleSelection) - qx.ui.form.RadioGroup (ISingleSelection) - qx.ui.tabview.TabView (ISingleSelection) - qx.ui.container.Stack (ISingleSelection)

Renamed MSelectionHandling to MMultiSelectionhandling for consistent naming. Deprecated old MSelectionHandling
Done with reversion 18989.
Closed.
mass renaming of 0.9 target to 1.0-beta1
corrected wrong milestone (was 0.9, but was fixed for 0.8.3 already)

The new ideas of the selection API.
